thread.title: How to sidestep one in three cancers in Australia
thread.title_full: How to sidestep one in three cancers in Australia | afr.com

author: Jill Margo
title: How to sidestep one in three cancers in Australia
text:
Drinking no more than two alcoholic drinks a day can radically reduce your risk of getting cancer. iStock Share on twitter Share on Google Plus by Jill Margo One in three cancers in Australia could be prevented if people made some simple changes to their lifestyle.
For the first time, a study has quantified the effect of positive lifestyle change and found 37,000 Australians could be spared a cancer diagnosis every year if such changes were made.
Smoking, UV radiation, body weight, poor diet and alcohol cause about 90 per cent of preventable cancers, the study shows.
When people make lifestyle changes and stick to them, evidence shows they can reduce their risk of developing cancer, even though they may already have done damage.
While there are no surprises in the list of preventable causes of cancer, the numbers attributed to each cause are surprising and show people how to cut their risk.
Alcohol alone is linked to 3200 cases of cancer in places like the colon, rectum, breast, mouth and throat, and liver. These cancers could be reduced by 1400 alone if Australians just stuck to the guidelines of no more than two drinks a day.
Each year smoking is linked to 15,525 cases in 13 places including less obvious locations such as the bowel, liver, kidneys and ureter, and stomach.
The study, funded by Cancer Council Australia and conducted by QIMR Berghofer Medical Research Institute, found the four most preventable cancers are lung, colorectal, melanoma and breast.
Get over the tan thing and use sunscreen. . iStock Although prostate cancer is the most common cancer diagnosed in Australia, it has no known preventable causes. David Whiteman, professor of epidemiology with QIMR Berghofer, who led the study, said while there was speculation about possible preventable causes, the two major authorities that make these determinations, The International Agency for Research on Cancer and the World Cancer Research Fund, had not formally agreed upon any.
He did say, however, that there was a view that obesity is likely to emerge as a causal factor for prostate cancer.
Whiteman says men have higher rates of cancer because, compared with women, they smoke and drink more, exercise less and eat a poorer diet.
The new study also excludes brain and occupational cancers because the data is not firm enough. Surprisingly, the data is also not reliable for medical radiation, delivered through Xrays and CT scans.
Quit smoking. Domino Postiglione The study did include the impact of some infections. It found the human papillomavirus, Helicobacter pylori and Hepatitis B and C caused the largest number of cancers. HIV and Epstein Barr caused fewer.
Sanchia Aranda, CEO of Cancer Council Australia, says it is time to focus on reducing the known risk factors.
